qas.question: Where were the Laws of the Game of Association Football published?

context: In <a0_0>1863<a0_0/>, the newly founded Football Association (the FA) published the Laws of the Game of Association Football, unifying the various different rules in use before then. On 20 July 1871, in <b9_0>the offices of The Sportsman newspaper<b9_0/>, the FA Secretary <a1_0><b5_0>C. W. Alcock<b5_0/><a1_0/> proposed to the FA committee that "it is desirable that a Challenge Cup should be established in connection with the Association for which all clubs belonging to the Association should be invited to compete". The inaugural FA Cup tournament kicked off in <a2_0>November 1871<a2_0/>. After thirteen games in all, <a3_0><b6_0>Wanderers<b6_0/> were crowned the winners<a3_0/> in the final, on 16 March 1872. Wanderers retained the trophy <b8_0>the following year<b8_0/>. The <a4_0>modern cup was beginning to be established by <b7_0>the 1888–89 season<b7_0/>,<a4_0/> when qualifying rounds were introduced.
